subject: Gianni to Illustrate 2014 Calendar
event: Cool news for everyone who likes great ICE & FIRE artwork (starting with me). The 2011 Ted Nasmith calendar and the 2012 John Picacio calendar both did very well, and Random House has extended our deal for three more calendars: 2014, 2015, and 2016 (the 2013, featuring art by Marc Simonetti, is already in the works, and will debut in July at the San Diego Comicon). And if that wasn't exciting enough, we've just signed GARY GIANNI to provide the art for the 2014 calendar! The comic book fans among you probably know Gianni best for his work on the PRINCE VALIANT comic strip in your Sunday paper, where he took on the daunting task of following in the footsteps of the immortal Hal Foster, and brought it off wonderfully. But I've been a huge fan of Gianni's ever since I first stumbled upon a copy of the Wandering Star limited edition of THE SAVAGE TALES OF SOLOMON KANE (my favorite Robert E. Howard character, fwiw). Until I saw the Wandering Star book, the notion that any other artist could ever do a Solomon Kane to compare to Jeff Jones's version would have struck me as rank heresy, but Gianni's art blew me away. Gianni went on from that to illustrate one of Wandering Star's gorgeous CONAN volumes, to provide some lovely interiors for Michael Chabon's GENTLEMEN OF THE ROAD, to Prince Valiant, and assorted other triumphs too numerous to mention. He's an amazing artist, and I cannot wait to see him bring my world and characters to life for the 2014 calendar. So now the only question is... who can we possibly get for 2015 and 2016?

comments.article:
Fantastic news!

I'm not sure about the contract details, (who employs the artists, etc..) but artists I'd love to see do a calendar are:

Alan Lee, John Howe, Jeffrey Jones, Michael Whelan , Keith Parkinson, Tom Canty, and, of course, longtime fans will recognize the name of Stephen Youll.

As I mentioned before, I'm not sure if he is still on good terms, but the fact that he did a piece for Dance Dragons (seen on his site) shows that he enjoys Ice and Fire. Side note: I think having him do a calendar the year the final Ice and fire book comes out would be awesome.

Of course, the cover artists for some of the Dunk & Egg stores would also be very welcome ((whose names I sadly can't find at this time).
Seconded John Howe - he's also an amazingly lovely chap, replied to all my emails and letters when I was at university.

Alas, Jeffrey Jones passed away last year.

I believe Youll also did that piece because some of the foreign publishers still wanted to use his cover art, but I'm sure he's a fan, and he'd be a nice one for a calendar.

And speaking of D&E cover artists, how could I forget Michael Kaluta? He was set to do the Dabel calendar follow-up when that went pear-shaped, and I would dearly love to see his work gracing new calendars.
My apologies & condolescenes - did not know that he passed.

did it ever get used on any editions outside the USA? It was to have been the cover for AFfC, but then Bantam decided to go with 'non-genre' cover designs for the new book and the re-issues of the first 3 books.

Steve displayed it at a WorldCon, half-jokingly put an amazingly high sale price on it, thinking no one would really spend that much, and before I could get George down to the art show to see it, someone had bought it right off the display and taken it off to their room!

Talk about the one that got away.....

Unfortunately, Keith Parkinson is also gone. He died a couple of years ago, before Jones.

Many of the artists on your list have illsustrated various limited editions of the books. Jeff Jones did the art for the Meisha Merlin GAME OF THRONES, and John Howe for their CLASH OF KINGS. Tom Canty illustrated the Subterranean Press edition of A FEAST FOR CROWS.

Yes, I am still on good terms with Stephen Youll. He and I had dinner last spring, when I was in NYC. Nice guy, fine artist. He's certainly be a name to consider.

Michael Whelan would be wonderful, to be sure, but at this point in his career, he is probably out of our price range.

Alan Lee might be a possibility, though. Another wonderful artist.

Gary is one of my favorite artists - we pen and ink guys have to stick together. And, should the need arise... here is what my art wall looks like now, with all the completed illos for THE DRAGONS OF WINTER. I think it would look just as sweet filled with ICE & FIRE calendar art. ;)

http://pics.livejournal.com/coppervale/pic/001e8r5a

He really does amazing work and I would love to see him do Drogon flying down into the fighting pits in Meeren or any artist for that matter that would be a sweet calendar pic unless it's already been done.
